segments.text: Okay.
Where will local school board members receive the training that is required by the State Board of Education?
I don't know.
I don't have any plans as to how that will occur.
That will have to be built in to the state's plans, like how to implement that piece of legislation.
How that will be designed and
I had no idea as to how this would happen at all.
I imagine that it will vary from one district to another and it will cost
the money.
I don't know the exact amount that's been appropriated for them.
Have they started this training yet?
Uh, see I don't have any access to the information about what I have.
I had my friends come in and give me some information.
except for those that we had been specifically studying at Texas A&M.

We did a study on the way the career ladder was being implemented, the way performance appraisal was being implemented, and we've taken a look at what people think about an entrepreneurship equation and advanced academic training.
Some of us have been participating in a group called Epsom's Equality Education.
But if you want an oral history of the committee, this question of how the recommendation is being implemented, in our features, they're not really linked to the committee.
That's only one .
OK. Why is a master teacher exam required in order for teachers to be assigned to level four on the career lab?
Let me raise a question about what you're trying to get at.
Ask me why.
an exam is required presumes a number of things.
It presumes, I think it's a good idea, which I don't, it presumes that all the members of the committee voted for all the recommendations, which they didn't.
There were many votes.
There were 14 to 6.
There were many different items that were voted.
And a number of those were six people who voted against the recommendation.
So I can't tell you why.
The reason, the reason why is because the law, the legislation, asked the legislation to require it.
That's why it's going to be done.
Now whether I think it's a good idea or not, I'd be happy to comment on it, right?
I don't think it's a very good idea.
I think there are other ways to determine whether teachers are competent, besides doing a certain basic skill.
You know, 20 years after they graduate, and they've done a very good amount of work, and many of them are very good teachers.
You know, it's a waste of money, financially, to presume that all 210,000 teachers
are not competent to teach.
You've got to give them this basic skillset plan.

It's going to cost $14 million to test these teachers, many of whom already have master's degrees and have already taken many courses in which they've demonstrated that they can spell and read and write.
Many of them have taken the graduate record at the time at the universities that they attended.
Those teachers don't need to be tested anymore.
And it's a slap in the face to a teacher who has a certificate.

If you say, you know, we're going to give you this one test, and if you don't pass it, even if you freeze on it, which is much better for some teachers, because so much will be riding on it, if you don't take your
You don't do that with lawyers or doctors or anybody else.
Another example of how the society mistreats its people.
And I didn't vote for that, I didn't do it.
In fact, I called the president of the Educational Testing Service and asked him to
And he told me over the phone, and I reiterated it to the committee,
That's what he said, that Abram would not allow that test to be used by anybody who flew to keep it in the mainland, because the test was not a test of Goblin, it was a test of Goblin.
And if the test was used in that way, it would be bad for the testing company, because it would not be creditable.
They would not be using the test for what it was intended.
And they refused to let Houston use it,
and they would not allow the state of Arkansas to use their test.
Furthermore, he said that if any teacher was excluded using their test, they would appear as a witness in court for the teacher, not for the school district.
So I played, I told
all the members of the committee, what the president of the largest test and test corporation in the United States has said about testing teachers.
And they've only four, three, or six to do it anyway.
And the reasoning behind that has a lot more to do with politics.
The politicians feel they need something to demonstrate to the public
that they're going to find out whether their tax increase is worth it.
In other words, whether it improves the quality of the school.
If you put more money in to keep the salary, what do you get for it?
And the fastest thing they go to to demonstrate quality is a test.
And toughness.
Get tough, get test.
Well, improving quality of life is more complicated than just being tough.
And if people go to school and threaten you, it benefits a lot to do with making things better rather than making things tough.
Just requiring more of something doesn't make it better.
Unless you change the interaction between the teacher, the student, and the curriculum,
you really haven't accomplished the whole lot.
You've got to get really good teachers.
And you don't get good teachers just by giving them, like, uh, cuts on paper cuts.
You get good teachers by using that $14 million to set up intensive training programs.
You can find out whether a teacher can teach their subject to the students by going into their class.
And in the performance appraisal instrument that states with and with and none, that's number nine in the list of competencies that they require teachers to demonstrate.
So they have a method for determining whether the teacher knows enough about their subject to teach it to students.
OK.
This master teacher exam, do you know if it has been created yet, or?
It all depends on which exam you're talking about.
There will be, as a result of this legislation, 97 new tests.
Some of these are for students, some are for teachers.
The tests for teachers started way back before Hospital 72.
There was a bill called Senate Bill 50 approved in the previous legislative session that required an examination
For teachers, prior to entry, you need to be familiar with the pre-professionals and skills test, it's called.
You have to take that prior to getting into teacher education.
And that's a test of math and English.
Then the next test is an exit exam.
And that's after the person completes the fourth year, prior to entry into the profession.
Then there's a test.
It's going to be given a one-shot test that will be given in March to all the current teachers.
And that test is a basic skills test.
There's another test for teachers in the career ladder plan between levels two and three, which is called an advanced test.
Nobody knows what that means yet.
In fact, nobody knows what levels three and four mean.
They haven't been worked out yet.
That's one of the things that got all of the experienced teachers very angry in Texas because all of the experienced teachers were put on level one.
And then a decision was made in each of the districts because there was money provided over and above the regular base salary by the state.
There was an advanced amount of money given to each district for merit.
and they had to set up a system of performance or presence to determine which teachers received merit.
But here were these teachers who'd been teaching for 20 years, and they all were now replaced on the first level with all the beginning teachers.
Okay.
Do you think sometime in the future that first-year teachers will eventually have to have a master's degree to begin teaching as opposed to a bachelor's degree?
I hope so.
There is a lot of activity right now in the profession moving that direction.
Florida has this requirement, five-year programs.
North Carolina is moving in that direction, Oklahoma.
And within the professional organizations, there's a new group called the Homes Group, 29 institutions, mostly land grant, research-oriented type universities.
and the large private institutions, like Stanford, Columbia, New York University, Harvard, are members of this group of 29.
In fact, they're just two weeks from expanding it to 35.
Their commitment is to develop five-year programs and also to study them, to do research on teacher education.
In addition to that, they have as a goal to set up a set of standards which they will apply to themselves.
Now, there are something like 1,340 institutions in the United States .
And this group is saying, look, to try to get all 1,340 of these institutions that meet these standards is impossible.
Those outstanding universities that are already research-oriented universities, committed to quality and committed to research, ought to be doing this kind of thing.
They ought to be setting up models of the best way to prepare teachers.
And of course, this is all going to be done in a kind of context of a teacher shortage.
So the conflict becomes, well, while you're developing these great program five-year models, there's going to be a shortage of teachers.
Are you going to meet the demands or numbers and still move in this quality domain?
The last meeting in Texas A&M is one of these 35 groups working with a home school.
In fact, I have a meeting.
November 11, in Washington, deal with the deans of education.

I'm meeting with the presidents and vice presidents of their institutions at the national meeting of the land grant universities to discuss how to work on this whole area as a university-wide activity, rather than just have colleges of education involved.
But the answer I'm hoping we give to that is, look,
If we can develop high quality programs in teacher education, in the end, that will produce more teachers rather than less.
Now, A&M is a good example of this.
We have increased our teacher education enrollment over the last four years by 34%.
We have higher requirements, grade point average requirements, and testing requirements to get into the College of Education than other colleges on the campus.
It doesn't hurt us at all.
It helps us.
We have a math science scholar loan program now.
We have nine National Merit Scholars, eight valedictorians.
We've got 30 students on scholarships.
All of this has been stimulated by commitment to quality.
And I think, in a long run, we drive students away by law and standards.
I think the school drives teachers away

by setting up emergency permit programs or alternative certification programs where people get in without meeting the strict requirements of performance, demonstrated competence, and having completed a good subject field preparation and a good student teaching preparation.
I think we destroy our recruitment approach when we lower standards.
not when we increase them.

And so I'm hoping that the land grant institutions can hold out on this and say, look, we believe it's important to prepare a group of people, teachers and professional leaders, and also show how it should be done and do research on it at the same time.
And I think that group could have a major impact on the other 1,300
institutions that exist.
And some of those should go out of the business.
They shouldn't be trying to prepare teachers, because in some cases, there's a half a faculty member trying to teach the whole science group.
How do you feel about all teachers and administrators having to take the competency exam in March 1986?
I don't think it's a good method for determining teacher competence.
And it's not done in any other profession.
And I think it's a slap in the face to the teachers and to the training institutions that prepared those people.
They're going to be giving that test to people who have master's degrees from some of the best institutions in the state.
In order to get into this institution, you have to have higher requirements than are going to be required on this test.
Why do you have to spend $14 million
to give 210,000 teachers a test as a political activity.
It's a total misuse of funds.
And there are other methods for determining what they want to determine.
But the emphasis on testing today suggests, and when they give the test, what are they going to have?
It's not going to be a test of teacher confidence.
I think it's a waste of time.
Okay.
Is this a one-time competency test that must be passed as a condition for further informant, or can it be retaken if failed?
They're saying it can be retaken, but it's a one-time test.
They won't give this every year because the people who will be coming in after this year to the profession
will all have taken the pre-proficiency skills test to get into teacher education in the first place and the exit exam in the subject field.
But those make sense because when you test a person on the pre-proficiency field, they're testing them on the first two years of college in terms of what they've studied in math and English.
So it has a reference.
The exit exam is on what they've been studying for four years in the subject field, which they're going to teach.
and the professional education that they've been studying.

The test is related to a curriculum, which is totally different than just pulling a test out of the air and giving it to teachers after 20 years of teaching without reference to anything that they've recently studied.
What is your opinion about the PPST exam?
English proficiency exam before the state even recommended the pre-proficiency skills test.
It's one set of evidence that we use in making the judgment of entrance.
I feel grade point average is just as significant recommendations from the people who've been the teachers of the students.
Observation of their work in the school and hearing that people
a chance themselves early in their program to go out and work with teachers and students in the schools to see if they really want to be a teacher.
Those are the kinds of things, in addition to the PPST that we do and that I think are essential in making judgments about at the point of matriculation before a person comes in to teacher education.
In most cases, people who don't want to be teachers learn that through those first two years
And most of them weed themselves out.
They decide not to become teachers.
It's a certain amount of self-serving.
What is your opinion about the exit exam that students preparing to be educators must take upon graduation from college?
My preference would be that the institutions design the test in relationship to the particular curriculum
that the institution has developed to prepare the teachers.
There's a great deal of similarity in some areas, but also an institution like ours, where we're moving toward five-year programs in some areas, and we're moving toward endorsements.
In addition to being an elementary teacher or a secondary teacher, here at A&M, you can pick bilingual education, reading, special education.
I would like to have them let us design our own tests, which they could then review to make sure they met their standards.
And then they come in to review teams and give us program approval based on their evaluation of what we're doing.
But I would leave it up to the institutions to design the test in relationship to the curriculum that they're teaching based on state standards.
The professional standards allow the institution, the economy, to go beyond the minimums in developing our programs.

And I would, in fact, hope the state would provide incentives for going beyond the minimums, rather than always being so concerned about whether we've met the minimum and then forgetting everything else.
What is your opinion about students having to pass all academic courses with at least a grade of 70 in order to participate in extracurricular activities?

I believe that to relate extracurricular activities to the rest of the curriculum and use it as a device, I believe the value of extracurricular activities can stand in their own without them being used
to have a student hostage to do better than I was subject to.
I think you can make a case for the educational value of so-called extracurricular activities.
For instance, when a student gets the experience of being managing editor of a school newspaper, or is organizing the school play, or is participating in the debate team,
In my estimation, the values that come from the learnings that come from those kind of activities are as valuable in many cases as students learning in the regular class.
So I don't think you use one to force the other.
I think there are other ways.
The answer to improving people's performance
in the academic classes is to make the curriculum as exciting as the extracurricular activities are, and not use the extracurricular activities as a threat.
What's been missing in the dialogue are the three other areas of extracurricular activities that the committee was very concerned about, and I agree we ought to move on those.
that there was an imbalance in the amount of money being spent for football and sports, not the other extracurricular activities.
I think some of the other extracurricular activities get shortchanged because of the emphasis on interscholastic sports.
I believe that interscholastic sports need to be de-emphasized and the other extracurricular activities emphasized more than they are, such as

with the music programs and the art programs at school, the cultural programs that schools should have on valuable kinds of experiences that are lacking because of the imbalance in the way that money is spent.
Secondly, the issue of the pull-outs that I strongly believe in what the committee recommended, that you ought to have the academic
programs in the course of the day.
And those ought to be saved for math, science, English, social science, and so forth.
And you shouldn't be pulling students out to go to band or to debating.
But you shouldn't eliminate debating or band.
They should have those in another portion of the day.
And that's a problem of scheduling.
It isn't a problem of doing away with one or the other.
And so I strongly believe in the committee's recommendation.
And that was the committee's recommendation.
It was not to do away with extroversion.
Now the third area was the imbalance in the way sports, especially, was affecting the academic quality of the faculty.
The whole idea of hiring people to be coaches and then asking the question, what can they teach, is the wrong sequence.
That's an imbalance in terms of priorities.

They should be asking, if there's an American history position open in the school, and you need American history, you ought to go out and find the best American history scholar who likes to work with students, young people, and can do that and make history exciting to them.
You ought to hire that person, and then somebody ought to ask, can that person coach?
And that's not being done enough.
In fact, in some schools,
They hire the head coach, and then he hires his assistants.
And then somebody says, well, what can we get him?
What can we have him teach?
Well, that's totally wrong.
That needs to be corrected.
Now, those three areas of imbalance in the financing of athletics and the pull-out problem and the influence on the quality of the faculty
haven't been discussed at all.
It's all no pass, no play that's being discussed.
Those other three areas, in my estimation, are just as critical as that issue, more critical than that issue.
Why did Scope make no pass, no play part of House Bill 73?
Primarily because of the looking for simple solutions to complex problems.
The whole idea that threat can be a motivation to get people to do something well that they aren't doing well by taking away from them something that they're doing a good job at.
And that, to me, is an example of a simple solution to a complex problem that doesn't work.
For some kids, it will work for a short period of time to threaten them.
But in the long run, it doesn't work.

The only way you can get students to do well in the academic courses is by setting up a specific educational plan to help them, to set up tutorial programs to give them that extra help they need, and to make the classroom experience exciting for them.
When you do that, the key to doing that is to having high quality teachers.
Instead of trying to use these mechanical mechanisms to threaten people, you really need creative teachers.
You need smaller classes, better curriculum materials.

You need the opportunity, the flexibility of the teacher to help students work at the level they're at and have them feel good about themselves and use success at the next level of their stage of intellectual development.
and challenge them there instead of giving them some task that they can't do and they feel like a failure.
The key to teaching is being able to differentiate instruction based on where that student is at the moment.
And not to give them an assignment that's so difficult it blows them over.
The key is to give them an assignment that pushes them to their next level of understanding.
And then they get into the next level above that by succeeding at that previous level.
But that takes differentiation and individualization.
And that takes schools where teachers have their time.
You can't do that with 200 kids in English.
Each student in English is at a different stage in their ability to write.
And you have to be working with them at the stage they're at.
Some kids can do college work while they're in the sixth grade.
And they ought to be allowed to proceed as far as they can.
Other kids may have
mild handicaps where they read from right to left rather than left to right.
They can't make sense out of letters.
They have dyslexia or something, some other problem.
So the teacher needs to use different approaches with those kids.
But a good school helps each student move as far as they can in terms of what they're able to do and still get them to feel good about themselves, not feel like a failure for life.
And that's what I'm worried about with these strict
models where everybody has to fit into the mold, and if they don't, they don't make it.
They're kicked out.
And five years from now, we may end up with the test averages going up, but when we take a look at it, we may find that the 20% of the kids who needed our help most are no longer in school.
There'll be more people passing the test, but the other kids will have dropped out.
And if that happens, we shouldn't call it reform.
And I don't think that's what the governor or the select committee or any other people had in mind.
They did this with the best intentions.
But it could happen if we don't take a close look at it.
In regard to the appraisal teams, do you think the one evaluator who must be from where the teacher is employed should be an administrator?
and why?
No, I think they should separate the administrator from the process of doing the evaluation.
I think they should do like they're doing in Tennessee, bringing in people from the outside, the outside evaluators, who are specialists in the teaching field and as the teachers teach.
This principal goes in there and he's not trained in physics to do an evaluation of the physics teacher or chemistry or science or
foreign language.
You need people who are trained in the subject areas and also trained to use the performance appraisal instruments.
And then you also want a situation where you separate the evaluation from the person who's going to have to make that decision and help that person over the rough spots.
You really need, in a school, people doing evaluations for merit and salary increases and promotions separate from evaluation from instruction improvement.

The people who are working with people on instruction improvement, if the principal's going to be an instruction leader, the teacher has to be able to go to that principal without any fear at all or threat and tell all the bad things about themselves, things they don't know what to do.
As a beginning teacher, for instance, you want to go in and say to the principal, boy, I'm having trouble with this.
It's very hard to say that if that same person is going to turn around and have to evaluate you for merit.
So you need these two systems of evaluation operating, one for instructional improvement and another for making judgments relating to personnel practices, such as salary increases and promotions.
And those have to be separated.
Are you for or against?
The same person can't do both.
It's a conflict of roles.
Are you for or against the appointed or elected state board of education?
I would like to see an elected state board with much more involvement of the local community in that process.
But I worry about putting all this power
and a few people who are appointed, and the political patronage that goes with these appointments to these boards.
Now, first time around, everybody agreed that this particular governor would bend over backwards to make sure there was no political basis for doing the appointment.
But there was an appointed board in Texas at one time, and they did away with it during the Elmore Aiken study.
And the reason they went away with it because it became a political patronage appointment process where, over time, the politicians used these appointments as a political activity.
And I believe that the more you take these kinds of roles out of the local community,
the less investment and sense of ownership the local area has in the whole business of education.
And I think that electing their officials to make these decisions is one of many of the things we ought to put back with the local board.
I believe we ought to have a bottom-up approach for educational change with the individual school as the focus for improvement, not a top-down approach where you get a few people
who are chosen because someone says we can't have any faith in these local boards, they're all controlled by the booster squad, and they'll be putting too much emphasis on athletics.
Well, the key to that is to emphasize that the local board has to take the responsibility for quality, not to say let's take over that role.
Because ultimately, a school is only as good
as that local community wants to make it.
You can't mandate quality for 1,089 school districts, 240,000 teachers, and 3.2 million children from the state and treat every school district as if they were one district.
And because the districts vary from one end of the state to the other in terms of size, in terms of makeup,
You've got the urban areas.
You've got the small West Texas towns.
But the key that you want is a commitment, regardless of the size of that district, of the local people in their schools to take the responsibility to make it good.
Not a few people in Austin.
OK.
If a student fails an academic course during the last six weeks of the academic school year,
Will that student be barred from participating in extracurricular activities like football during the first six weeks of the following academic school year?
I don't know how they rule it on that.
We'll have to wait and see how that turns out.
Do you feel that scope was adequately represented with educators?
No, I don't.
That was the only question.
education on the committee.
There were no teachers, there were no principals, there were no superintendents.
The committee would have been a much different committee if it had teachers on it.
There would have been a much more sensitivity and greater feeling as to what the life of a teacher is like.
One of the issues that are raised by teachers when they try to differentiate programs based on

the wide differentiation in where students are in terms of what they're trying to teach, in terms of reading groups, levels of reading in any given class, the diversity that you find within any given class, and how you have to go about designing specific teaching strategies to meet the needs of those different learners.
The committee really
tried to get a sense of the pieces by listening to a lot of them coming into the meeting.
And also, in the testimony, all the professional groups had a chance to come before the committee.
And Perot, Mr. Perot, really did a good job, I think, in hiring Sorolla to get this information on this survey.
But we did not have this constant input and confrontation in the subcommittee.
that was very essential, would be very essential to have with teachers in an ongoing way.
And I think the credibility of the committee would have been strengthened by having people fund education, more people for education on the committee itself.
Do you think House Bill 72 made the teaching profession a rewarding one to attract good teachers and retain good teachers?
Some aspects of it can
do that if they're properly implemented.
The highest salary was essential.
The scholar loan programs that were developed and that have been implemented, but there's not enough money there.
Really, we're talking about a million dollars for pre-service students.
I forgot the exact amount of money for career teachers who want to shift from the teaching field they're in now to the high priority area, the shortage area.

But they didn't fund some aspects of the research and development to try to provide funds where industry and the schools and colleges could come together to develop model programs, innovative programs that would go beyond the minimum standard.
We need to do a lot more with providing tutors to back up the teachers when they make recommendations that students need tutoring.

For the first time in the history, there's a lunch program now where the teacher's supposed to have free lunch duty of at least a half hour, but in some school districts, they're not giving them this.
They still have to eat with the kids.

The conditions in the workplace, the smaller classes would have made a great deal of difference, but those are the first things that the districts are asking for waivers on because they say they don't have the teachers or the space to provide the smaller classes.
A lot's going to happen, and a lot's going to depend on what happens, for instance, with things like the career ladder, too.

That could be a terrific program if we can get in shape what the career level three and four requirements are going to be in terms of role definitions and increased incentives for becoming a trainer of beginning teachers and things like this.
But all that has yet to be worked out.
See, the salary is only one thing that creates a profession.
It's basically the knowledge base, what kind of training they have, and we need to do a lot more about that.
Teachers have to have a lot more autonomy in terms of the governance structure.
We have to rely on teachers themselves to set the standards and monitor them.
Actually, this bill took away from the Commission on Professional Standards much of its authority because the school state board itself now
can give approval for local districts to set up alternative certification programs and bypass the commission of professional standards completely.
So that was a step backward for the profession.
The conditions in the workplace may be more important in many respects than the salary.
If these essential elements requirements, which are requiring much more paperwork,
The more the paper shuffling gets foisted on the teachers, we're going to drive a lot of them out of teaching.

If you hand a teacher a syllabus and say, make sure everybody in this class is on page such and such on October 13th, and we're going to judge how good you are by giving them all a test, it changes the whole nature of teaching from a very creative process in which that teacher who loves their subject teaches it in the most creative ways possible.
and then gets the students turned on instead of trying to do this workbook thing with these essential elements and then fill out the form.

And a lot's going to happen in terms of the way the state loosens up and gets back to providing some of these teachers to trust them and have faith in them and give them some autonomy to teach these basic skills programs and beyond in creative ways.
They'll take good leadership.

I would like to see the state move toward a system where the better a school became, the more autonomy it would have, and reward them for being good by letting them develop innovative ways to do things, and not treat every school as if it was the same.
Those schools which aren't doing a good job should be declared bankrupt, and the state should go in and do everything they can
We're those, but not to put all of these minimum regulations on all of these really good school districts.
Those good school districts ought to be rewarded by saying, do better.
Think of creative things on your own that you can do to go beyond where you are, and the state then ought to provide incentives to help you do that.
That's what will keep good teachers in teaching.
If they have a chance to be creative and innovative and then get rewarded
But the hard work it's going to take to go beyond the minimums.
OK. What are the bad parts of Haskell 72?
Well, I think the overemphasis on testing as an indicator of excellence.
There are many more ways to define excellence than just test scores.
You know, I think that the...
aspects of the bill with the over-emphasis on threat as the primary means for motivation, the whole business of the no more than five days absent.
Here, kids, you see, those kinds of things, the regulations, when you try to implement those, having been a principal of a school and a teacher, I know that you need the flexibility in a school.
The assumption is if you don't have those rules, kids will
you know, not, they'll abuse them.
Well, there are other ways to get kids to go to school other than having those rules.
You may have a situation, for instance, where you have a migrant farm worker student who, in order to keep the family going, has to work during certain times of the year.
We used to be the kids where any day you could get that child in school, you were happy to get them there.
You wanted to get them there.

And now that kid misses five days of school, and he might as well stay out of school for the whole semester, because even if he comes back, which he's not going to when you sit there and not get any credit for it, he misses the five days, he loses the whole semester, which is absurd.
What you want to do is set up a system where you get him in school as many days as you possibly can working.
That's going to be a system where after five days, after they miss five days, they'll give up.
It's just like having this six weeks as a suspension time for people who don't get past these minimum grades.
This doesn't make any sense.
Why six weeks?
Why can't you make it on a system of week by week?
And working with a student to progress and helping them succeed.
Not use it as punishment.
Use it as a means of motivation and incentive
But somebody's got to work with the student.
It doesn't do any good to just say you can't participate for six weeks.
Somebody ought to be working with that student before they get to the situation where they don't pass.
And then if they don't pass, somebody ought to be working with them right off.
And there ought to be some incentives, some goal set.
And then if the student meets those goals, then you
Move ahead and help you feel like a success if you don't do things in terms of six-week chunks.
People who are 15 and 16 don't live their lives that way.
They don't think of those things.
We're going to lose a lot of kids from school.
The thing I'm hoping that somebody does is hold each of these school districts to the requirement in the legislation that they do.
